newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila says new tax package being finalised.
newsitem.headline: Manila says new tax package being finalised.

text.p: The Philippine government is optimistic a new tax package aimed at replacing a complicated and widely abused system will be virtually complete by the end of the year, a senior official said.

"We are optimistic that the comprehensive tax reform package will pass. The final version should come through by the end of the year," Finance Secretary Roberto de Ocampo told reporters late on Monday.
The package is crucial to the government's economic reform programme because it is designed to ensure a sustainable source of revenue.
But its implementation has been delayed in the legislature because of differing views over how beer and cigarettes should be taxed.
The package includes three parts. The first, on oil products, has already been approved. The second, on beer and cigarette taxes, is pending in the legislature.
The government hopes the third part of the package, which concerns individual taxes, will be finalised next year.
De Ocampo said the passage of the taxes on beer and cigarettes would mean the package was virtually complete because the last part was certain to be passed.
"The last part is individual taxes...this is less controversial and passage should be easy," he said.
De Ocampo told reporters the tax reform package was one of the most important tasks before the government to ensure the benefits of economic reform were sustained.
The Philippines had the lowest tax collection rate among East Asian countries, he said.
A Department of Finance official said national statistics showed at least seven million people should pay income tax but only some 2.6 million people pay.
About 200,000 firms were registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission but only 70,000 filed returns and of these an even smaller amount paid tax.
